title: Lights, camera, action! Hoyts eyes off Palace Cinemas
text:
Wanda bought Hoyts back in 2015 for about $1 billion. The Chinese giant now controls 15 per cent of the world's box office across its portfolio of about 1600 cinemas. Of that, Hoyts' 53 cinemas in Australia and New Zealand is said to contribute a significant portion of the publicly listed Wanda's net profit.

Hoyts' main competitors in the Australian market are Event Hospitality & Entertainment, Village Roadshow and Reading Entertainment. According to IBISWorld, Hoyts generated $358 million of revenue in the 2019 financial year.

The sale interest comes amid a period where Hoyts has been spending big as it battles for viewers against a rising number of streaming services like Netflix, Stan, Disney+ and Amazon Prime.

The 110-year-old cinema business has spent more than $300 million upgrading the experience it offers, investing in luxury seating and cafes and bars at its cinema complexes. In Australia, Hoyts has renovated 80 per cent of its 40 cinemas in its fight against what's been dubbed a new golden age of television.

Hoyts chief executive Damian Keogh said this week the investment was to "create the cinema of the future".

Interestingly, cafes and bars are also part of Palace's cinemas. The boutique chain offers curated wine lists and gourmet foods at its locations.

While it's early days in the sale process for Palace – and adviser sources close to the deal emphasised Hoyts was not the only interested party – Street Talk is getting the popcorn ready and is excited to see how this movie ends.
description: Australia's second-largest cinema business Hoyts is looking to purchase the boutique, family-owned Palace Cinemas chain.
